captions.text:
As you probably know by now, we’ve been
working with Google and YouTube to answer

ten of the most popular science questions
asked on the internet.

And I gotta hand it to you, because there
are few questions that are as confounding

and complex and fascinating and inspiring,
as this one the collective consciousness has
spewed forth:
What is energy?

I'm Hank Green, and this is the World’s
Most Asked Questions.
[Intro]

Energy is everything. It’s everywhere. It’s
one of the true constants of the universe,

because as long as there’s been a universe,
there’s been energy.

And while it comes in lots of different forms
that can seem different to us, they all amount

to the same thing: Energy is the ability to
do work.

And work is just the act of displacing something
by applying force.

So, say you stomp on a stomp rocket. The force
of your foot hitting the pedal is turned into

the force of air leaving the cannon -- sending
your rocket sailing.

Or maybe you're enjoying a nice patty melt
-- the energy from that food is broken down

for all of the quadrillions of cells that
you have to do all of the things that they

have to do -- make copies of your DNA, assemble
and repair proteins, transport materials from

one place to another, make muscle cells contract
-- you know, all the stuff of being alive.

That rocket sailing, your cells toiling away,
your phone or computer being on right now
to watch me -- that’s all work being done.

And the ability to do these things is inherent
in everything around you. Even things that

look inert, completely lacking in energy.
Like this log.

This log, for example, is chock full of chemical
energy because it’s made up of combinations

of carbon and hydrogen and oxygen formed into
lignin, which is the stuff that makes up wood.

All of the bonds between all of those atoms,
in every molecule of lignin, contain energy.

How do I know? Because if I were to apply
enough extra energy, like as heat, to break

those bonds -- it would release that chemical
energy as fire.

That chemical energy also the kind of energy
you get from that patty melt -- your body

is fueled by the chemical bond energy in sugars,
fats, and proteins.
But this log also contains nuclear energy!

Each atom in this wood has a nucleus, made
of protons and neutrons, and the energy that

binds them together is one of the most powerful
sources of energy in the universe.

If you could split one of the atoms of carbon
or hydrogen in this log, and rip those protons

and neutrons apart, it’d release some of
that energy. There’s so much nuclear energy

in each atom that, if I could unleash all
of it that's in this log? There’d be a giant

smoldering crater where I’m standing and
everyone in the town of Missoula, Montana
would be dead.

So, everything that’s made of atoms has
nuclear energy locked up in it, but also,

it turns out, that mass and energy are the
same thing!

You might have heard of this little equation
that a German patent clerk came up with about
a hundred years ago: E = mc2.

And there are SO MANY OTHER KINDS of energy
that I’d love to get into if we had the
time ...

.. but even though they may seem different,
they can all be used to do work, whether it’s

driving a turbine, or moving a engine piston,
or allowing the screen on your tablet to glow.

Or, if it’s that most mysterious of energies,
dark energy, causing the universe to expand
more than it seems like it should.
But here’s the thing to remember.

Once the work is done, the energy isn’t
done.
Because energy never goes away.

It can never be destroyed, and in the same
way, it can never be created.

It can only be transferred from one source
to another -- like, how the energy in the

plants and animals that were in the patty
melt were transferred into you -- or it can

be transferred from one form into another
-- like the chemical energy in the wood being
transferred to light and heat as fire.

You could think of the universe as a constant
flow of energy, and we are just little pit
stops along the way.

Everything your body is doing right now -- whether
it’s your lungs absorbing oxygen, your heart

pumping blood, your brain cells firing as
you watch me and learn things -- all those

things are using recycled energy that’s
been around since the origin of the universe.

And by simply being alive, you’re releasing
that energy back into the environment around
you, to be used by other things in other ways.

So Internet, to answer your question: Energy
is everything.

And for those of you who answered our questions
on our SciShow survey, where you feel like

you get your energy may be keeping you up
at night. Survey takers who have a hard time

falling asleep nearly every night get their
energy from knowledge first, second from purpose.
Least likely? From exercise.

Of all the fascinating questions in the world,
what question do you want to see answered

most? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or
down in the comments down below and we will

aim to answer those questions in a new video
at the end of the month.

title: World's Most Asked Questions: What Is Energy?

comments.author: Matt Jordan

comments.text:
+Matt Jordan Energy is conserved if the Universe as time symmetry, which it 
seems to do. However, there's a large discontinuity in this symmetry at the 
Big Bang, so it's not exactly certain conservation of energy will hold (or 
even if there was a 'before' the Big Bang, time being a property of the 
Universe). It's very much still an open question in physics.
comments.author: Natasha Taylor

Ok. But there is one thing I don't understand: all the energy released as

comments.author: ΑΛΙΚΗ ΣΤΥΛΙΑΝΙΔΗ

comments.text:
+ΑΛΙΚΗ ΣΤΥΛΙΑΝΙΔΗ Generally, that energy just gets radiated away. 
Low-temperature heat gets emitted and turned into kinetic (thermal) energy 
of molecules, which can get radiated as even lower temperature heat, until 
eventually the photon escapes into space, never doing anything useful 
again. And so systems gradually wind down as their energy is flung away.
comments.author: Natasha Taylor

comments.text:
Actually, in order to get nuclear energy from elements liter than Iron 
(like Carbon, Hydrogen, Oxygen, and many others) you need to fuse them 
rather than split them. Because lowest energy state for nuclei is Iron 
nucleus, so heavier elements tend to split, while lighter element tend to 
give out tons of nuclear energy when fusing together (this for example 
happens in Sun all the time)﻿

comments.text:
I wonder if it would be possible for a nucleus to split on its own, 
starting a chain reaction that split every nearby atom and so and so on. 
That would be bad. And why aren't those atoms just crushed by all the 
weight? For instance, like 100 ton bricks or however large something with 
like mass has on atoms. I guess they're just tough little bastards. So, 
what makes them so tough?﻿
comments.author: Solace Creat

comments.text:
The first thing would be a "nuclear chain reaction". This process may 
happen under very specific circumstances and is for example a part of how 
nuclear bombs work.
 
Secondly the atoms aren’t “crushed” because of the forces between the 
particles themselves. This may be explained with electromagnetic forces, 
which would greatly exceed the strength of the gravitational pull of our 
home planet.
 
Furthermore, particles on the scale of atoms aren’t “crushed” in a daily 
life sense, because the physics we apply on macroscopic objects don’t quite 
work. On those scales particles are usually described as both a wave and a 
particle at the same time. Depending on how one may examine an atom either 
one or the other overweighs. (Basics of quantum physics.)

comments.text:
I have a question. What is gravitational energy and how does it work. Like 
how does the earth hold everything on it and not let it flow into the 
vacuum of space.﻿
comments.author: ryan lyninger

comments.text:
+ryan lyninger In lieu of anyone else giving you an answer, I'm going to 
try to be as not-disappointing as I can, but keep in mind that this is 
going to end in 'because that's the way the Universe works.' I also 
apologise in advance if the formatting is bad; YouTube has a stupid habit 
of deleting white space.

Gravitational potential energy is a type of energy known as 'potential 
energy'. This energy is caused by an objects position in a force field 
(that is, a field that applies a force) — in the specific example of the 
Earth, that force field is gravity, caused by massive objects wanting to be 
near each other. Your body is held together by the electric potential 
energy of electrons and protons, and the nuclei are held together by their 
nuclear potential energy. The reason we don't go flying off the surface of 
the Earth is because it requires energy to do so. Our position in the 
'force field' that is Earth's gravity gives us a potential energy (relative 
to infinity) of –6*10^7 J/kg. This means that we need 6E7 J to fling a 
single kilogram off the Earth (this is why space travel is so hard).

However, all I've done is offload the question — the next reasonable 
question would be 'how does the gravitational force field work?', and the 
answer to that would be 'because that's the way the Universe works.' It is 
a property of matter that it attracts other matter, and while we have 
possible explanations for this ranging from the very fabric of space-time 
being distorted to tiny gravitons carrying a gravitational charge, 
providing those answers only moves the 'because that's the way the Universe 
works' back one step farther.

One can easily imagine a Universe where there is no gravity, or where 
gravity can be repulsive, or where gravity goes down by the inverse cube of 
distance — gravity seems to work as it does as a fundamental property of 
the Universe.

comments.author: Stevie King

comments.text:
+Stevie King Yes. In particle accelerators we often use energy to create 
equal parts matter and antimatter (to satisfy conservation laws), and we 
can combine these two to make energy again. If you want to do it without 
antimatter, look at nuclear fusion/fission -- that is all about turning the 
mass of nuclei into energy.

comments.author: princespeach90

comments.text: What were to happen if you pulled an atom apart? Why?﻿
comments.author: JULIANQUINTERO

comments.text:
+JULIANQUINTERO Presuming you mean 'atom' in the sense 'nucleus + 
electrons', then what happens is that you get an ion. In general this 
process takes energy.If you mean 'atom' in the sense of 'atomic nucleus', 
it depends on the nucleus! A large nucleus (generally larger than iron, 
with some small exceptions) when pulled apart will release energy -- this 
is because it has more mass as a giant nucleus than the two smaller nuclei 
do combined. For a *stable* nucleus smaller than iron, it will take energy 
to pull apart, because the individual pieces have more mass than the 
combined nucleus. For *unstable* nuclei lighter than iron, it releases 
energy for the same reason as the large nuclei.
comments.author: Natasha Taylor

comments.text: Awwwww.... Now I want a patty melt﻿
comments.author: Bradley Burns

comments.text: How Large Exactly Is Our Universe?﻿
comments.author: james best

comments.text:
+james best As near we can tell it's infinite. The observable Universe has 
an apparent radius of 13.7 billion light years (that's all the distance 
light can have travelled since the Big Bang), but because the space in 
between then and now has expanded the 'actual' size (called the 'comoving 
distance') is about 46 billion light years.

comments.text:
When will the sun die out?

              SPAM THIS QUESTION!!!﻿
comments.author: Dean Winters

comments.text:
+Dean Winters In about five billion years it will become a white dwarf (and 
so cease nuclear fusion) and then it will spend the rest of eternity 
cooling down unless one of three things happens (written in increasing 
order of time taken to happen):1) Something collides with it that is large 
enough to destroy it;2) Nucleons in nuclei are unstable and it gradually 
decays away;3) The minimum mass for a back hole is less than its mass, in 
which case it will quantum-tunnel into a black hole.

comments.author: michal b

comments.text: What is radiation? And how does it effect our body?﻿
comments.author: Palvan Bekdurdiyev

comments.text:
+Palvan Bekdurdiyev There are two types of radiation, ionising and 
non-ionising. The most common form of non-ionising radiation is 
electromagnetic, and it can have various impacts on our body, ranging from 
'none' (e.g. radio waves), to heating us up (e.g. infrared light) to 
stimulating chemical transitions enabling us to see (visible 
light).'Ionising radiation' comes in two general forms -- particle and 
electromagnetic -- but both affect our body in the same way. They possess 
enough energy to knock an electron off an atom in our body, which makes 
that atom incredibly chemically reactive. For some atoms (such as the ones 
on the surface of your skin), this doesn't really matter, but if it's an 
atom in DNA it can damage something important for cellular function and 
trigger cell death or rampant cell growth (cancer).The ionising 
electromagnetic radiation are ultraviolet, x-rays and gamma rays, while the 
ionising particle radiation tends is either charged particles such as 
protons, electrons or positrons, or neutral particles (neutrons). Charged 
particles are much easier to stop because they're much likely to react with 
something (like the air or a sheet of paper) before they reach you.
comments.author: Natasha Taylor
